title: Using Img2Bytes: Visual Guide
description: Learn how to convert images to byte arrays for Arduino and embedded displays using the Img2Bytes GUI app.
author: SanjuOS Dev

contentBlocks.text: Converting images for embedded displays like OLED and TFT screens can be tricky. The **Img2Bytes** app makes it simple — upload an image, configure your display settings, and get ready-to-use C/C++ code.

contentBlocks.title: Open the App
contentBlocks.text: Find **Img2Bytes** in your SanjuOS app drawer and tap to open. You'll see an upload zone and settings panel.

contentBlocks.title: Upload Your Image
contentBlocks.text:
Click the upload zone or drag and drop your image file. Supported formats: PNG, JPG, GIF, WebP, BMP.

For animations, you can upload multiple images — they'll play in sequence!

contentBlocks.title: Choose Canvas Size
contentBlocks.text:
Select a preset matching your display:

- **128×64** — SSD1306 OLED (most common)
- **128×32** — SSD1306 Mini
- **240×240** — ST7789 Square
- **320×240** — ILI9341 TFT

Or enter custom dimensions for other displays.

contentBlocks.title: Configure Color Mode
contentBlocks.text:
Choose how colors are processed:

- **Mono** — 1-bit black/white (smallest size, works on all displays)
- **Grayscale** — 8-bit shades of gray
- **RGB565** — 16-bit color (common for TFT)
- **RGB888** — 24-bit full color

contentBlocks.title: Dithering
contentBlocks.text: For mono mode, try **Floyd-Steinberg** or **Atkinson** dithering. It creates a gradient effect using patterns of black and white pixels, making photos look much better!

contentBlocks.title: Preview & Adjust
contentBlocks.text: Watch the live preview update as you change settings. Adjust the **threshold** slider to control black/white balance. Toggle **invert** if your display has inverted colors.

contentBlocks.title: Copy or Download
contentBlocks.text:
Once happy with the preview:

1. Click **Copy** to copy the C array to clipboard
2. Or click **Download** to save as a `.h` header file

Paste into your Arduino sketch and you're ready to display!
The `PROGMEM` keyword stores the array in flash memory instead of RAM — essential for large images on Arduino!
